Microsoft Flight Simulator is a great game, or at least a solid base for addons. If you want a more arcade-style experience, the default Asobo A320 is fine. But if you want true realism, youâ€™ll need high-quality addons, either payware or some of the excellent free options available.

The graphics are impressive, and I get around 40 FPS on the ground with a 3060 12GB and a 7600X. The best part is that you can fly anywhere in the world. While the default airports arenâ€™t the highest quality, there are many great freeware options, and payware airports are available too.

A joystick â€” or at least an Xbox controller â€” is almost essential. Flying with a keyboard is very unrealistic.

The learning curve can be steep if youâ€™re new to flight simulation, but there are built-in tutorials that help you get started. The community is also great, with lots of guides, YouTube videos, and helpful people on forums.

Multiplayer is fun, especially with live traffic and real weather, which make the world feel alive. Loading times can be long, but the experience is worth it once youâ€™re in the air.

If you want an even more realistic experience, I highly recommend trying VATSIM â€” an online network where you can fly with real people acting as air traffic controllers. It adds a WHOLE NEW level of immersion.

Overall, an amazing simulator and absolutely worth it if you love aviation. Highly recommended!

Microsoft Flight Simulator 2020
----------------------------------------
Microsoft Flight Simulator 2020 has honestly become my go to chill game.
There is something weirdly satisfying about taking off smoothly and pretending I know what every button does.

Flying over places I have actually visited feels oddly nostalgic even if I sometimes mix up the airports.
The graphics are genuinely impressive and make it easy to just wander around the world from my chair.
I tried doing a serious flight plan once and ended up completely off course because I forgot to check the wind.

Landing is still the part where I either feel like a genius or a complete clown.
Even when I mess up it never feels frustrating, just funny in a very "yep that was definitely my fault" kind of way.

There is a nice sense of calm cruising above the clouds like free therapy but louder.
I love zooming in on random landmarks and discovering places I never knew existed.
Long flights are great background vibes while I listen to music or pretend I am a real pilot.
Short flights are perfect when I just want to relax for a few minutes.
The game somehow makes the whole world feel closer and smaller in a good way.
It is honestly one of those games that makes you smile without trying too hard.

Enjoy the game and flight

Then I can enjoy a set up in-air flight from Giza, over the Great Pyramid and the Sphinx, and land in Cairo Airport. The flight training includes Airbus Airline flight training. All this, and I can turn on stunning VR mode and feel like I'm really flying the airplane thousands of feet above the ground myself. This looks and plays so much better than the history of flight version and Flight Simulator X previous editions. Even flying a Helicopter feels real, especially in VR. This was the flight simulator I've been waiting for.

imagine for a moment.

you choose to fly between two random airports in the heart of the swiss alps. the distance between them is 60NM.
you choose the cessna 152.
you have no gps and no autopilot, and you have to deduce your position from little navmap and using maps and compass.
you climb up to 11k feet using loops because you have no room to climb.
you assume there's a lake some NM in front.
you don't find it.
you're lost.
you're desperate to find something that resembles a lake.
you find a huge lake on the corner of your eye that's not the one you're looking for.
you beeline towards it and try to crossreference it on little navmap.
you realize you're approaching italy and you're stranded another 60NM south of the target airport.
you try to deal with the updrafts and downdrafts while amending your flight plan on little navmap.
you fly the course as accurately as possible.
you're running low on fuel.
you have all eyes everywhere trying to find the damn airport.
in the right eye you see something that looks dark gray on the floor in a small valley.
it's not a road.
it's a runway.
you dive 6k feet down below while trying not to overspeed the aircraft.
you enter the flight pattern and land.
you take dozens of pictures.

that's where you realize: you just discovered the best hobby in the world.

One of the VERY few games that i actually take seriously.
Being in a virtual airline really adds a whole new level onto the experience. However here is my review:

[b]The Graphics;[/b]
Unless NASA let you borrow some hardware from the International Space Station, you'll be running this on High or lower. And that's okay. 

[b]Gameplay;[/b]
At the start, it is VERY confusing. If you want to take the game seriously enough, most of your time will be staring at Reddit articles and youtube videos on "how do flight sim". Once you've found an aircraft that you're happy with (For me it was the Fenix Simulations A320 family. However if you're not willing to drop â‚¬90 on that, then go with the FlyByWire A32NX). It gets sooo much better. You actually stressing less and enjoying the game more.

[b]Base Game Content;[/b]
The base game content (for the standard edition) is fine. good enough to get started with the game, however (imo) to really start enjoying the game, you need addons. A third party aircraft, GSX, Charts Software and VatSIM or BeyondATC are a must.

[b]Controls;[/b]
Get yourself a controller at least. Once you're into it start considering spending some money. For starting I'd go for the Logitech Saitek Yoke or the WinWing URSA MINOR Airline Joystick. And an actual hands-on throttle quad. For now (until my preorder for the WW/Airbus Throttle is done) go for the Thrustmaster Airbus Quadrant Captains Edition.

truly extraordinary. once you get past the initial phase of "flying around", and get into the nuances of navigation, engine management, flying the plane, managing the engines, various onboards systems, ATC, radios, GPS, and all the other things involved, the brilliance of this simulator really comes to life. it just gets better and better.

This game saved my life.

I am 39.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and adopted our son together. They are now both 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I found myself lost and miserable. I was self destructive. I got so mad one day from everything spiraling out of my control that I punched some concrete in a moment of overwhelming emotion. That caused me to break my 5th metacarpal in my right hand... my working hand... my games hand.. the hand that I held and carried my children to bed with.. The hand I desperately needed to make sure I could continue to provide.

After learning of the severity of my self-inflicted damage, I was borderline suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man with no history of depression or anxiety. I have never had fits of rage, or been one to break down and cry, but I was in a low spot that just really buried me from being able to see the light on the other side.

Having nothing better to do, I searched for a game I could play, ONE HANDED while I recovered. I somehow stumbled upon this game and read some of the reviews. I decided that it had to be worth a shot... I must admit, I didn't beat the game, or play nearly as long as some of you. In fact, I may have only played this game a day or two.. With that being said, after doing so, I had a new found joy and hope for life. I was able to put behind me the pain and suffering that had been cast over me. I was able to experience other peoples joy and happiness. I was able to see the fruits of my "labor". I relaxed for 5 â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ing minutes to this music long enough to realize that I was going to be okay.

After coming to that realization, I turned the game off, and I went back to work. It hurt my hand like hell but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so damn sorry for myself, and I became the father I needed to be in that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving as.

Today, I am close friend with my kids mother. We don't fight, or argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents, and friends.

I now have 3 kids. My third child is, wait for it, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my own separation, and we just stumbled in to each others life unexpectedly. We have been in a relationship for a year now, and are very happy together.

Moral of the story, you never know what life holds in store for you, and if I would have given up when all the odds were stacked against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

Thank you.
